[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures may impede immediate clarity.
[LEXICON]: Some archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "aromacular", "quasi-biological", "sinewy suppleness") might challenge casual readers.

[STRUCTURE]: The text jumps between personal anecdote, philosophical explanation, and academic critique without clear transitional markers.
[CLARITY]: Assumed knowledge of Spencer's works and 19th-century scientific context may leave some readers disconnected from the narrative's flow.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "It will perhaps be said...")
[LEXICON]: Archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "suppleness", "nonconformist", "encephalon" not present but "suppleness" is in context, however "strenuously" and "honoured" are in the current segment)

[LOGIC]: Assumptive statements without clear evidence ("It will perhaps be said...", "Did he not himself provide...")
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing Spencer's later years to analyzing the scope of his philosophy
[CLARITY]: Overly abstract concepts without sufficient elaboration for clarity (e.g., the explanation of "the Unknowable" and "Ultimate Reality")
